title: Is Boris Johnson likely to get the numbers to pass his Brexit deal?
text:
Brexit hinges on today’s Commons vote (Picture: Reuters)

Today’s Brexit vote in the House of Commons is ‘too close to call,’ according to experts.

Boris Johnson needs to get a majority of MPs to back him and his bid to leave on October 31.

It is a simple numbers game and the PM will be reliant on rebel Labour MPs and former Tories to back his plan, agreed with the EU on Thursday.

But what is the current make-up of the Commons and how are the numbers looking?

Who will back Boris? (Picture: EPA)

How many votes does he need?

There are 650 seats in the House of Commons. The Speaker, John Bercow, and his three deputies will not vote.

Sinn Fein’s seven MPs do not take their seat in Westminster on political grounds.

Assuming every other MP votes, then Boris Johnson needs to get 320 votes to give his deal a majority.

Who will vote for it?

The majority of Tories are on board and indeed backed previous versions of the deal put forward by Mr Johnson’s predecessor Theresa May.

There are 287 Tories but a number of the hardcore Tory Brexiteers could be swayed by the DUP’s decision to reject.

Leader of the hardline European Research Group (ERG) Steve Baker is playing his cards close to his chest but other members – including Jacob Rees-Mogg – have made positive noises.

This leaves Mr Johnson trying to win over Labour rebels and some of the 21 Tories that he sacked when they voted to make a no-deal Brexit illegal.

Early reports suggest he has 303 people on board – short of 17.

Boris cannot rely on the support of Jeremy Corbyn (Picture: AFP)

Who won’t vote for it?

The SNP has 35 MPs and say they will vote down Mr Johnson’s deal. The Lib Dems 19 politicians will also reject it.

Crucially, the DUP – former allies of the Tories – have also said they will reject the new deal because it keeps Northern Ireland still tied to a number of EU trade rules.

The Independent Group for Change (TIG) now has five MPs, made up of anti-Brexit Labour and Conservative defectors. They are pushing for a second referendum and won’t vote in favour.

Plaid Cymru’s four MPs and the Green Party’s Caroline Lucas have also said they will vote against the plan.

Labour’s 242 MPs have been ordered to vote against the deal.

However, there are nine who are likely to rebel and back the plan while a further 15 are said to be undecided.

Early reports suggest there are 301 confirmed to oppose Mr Johnson.

Leader of the House of Commons Jacob Rees-Mogg will back his friend Mr Johnson (Picture: AFP)

Are there any who haven’t made up their minds?

There are 15 Labour MPs who are yet to decide what to do and around 14 Tories.

The Labour MPs are in Leave constituencies and while they are not impressed by Mr Johnson’s deal are likely to back it to avoid trouble at any forthcoming general election.

And then there are the independents. Mr Johnson kicked out 21 Tories when they backed the Benn Act, which made no-deal illegal and would force the PM to ask the EU for an extension.

Many of those are likely to back a deal but around six are said to be undecided.

Some hardline Tories are unimpressed that Northern Ireland remains tied to the EU so could vote against the deal.

The ERG consistently voted down Mrs May’s deal but could still be persuaded by Boris in the next few hours.

Early reports suggest there are 35 who are undecided or have yet to announce either way. Therefore the fate of the nation rests in their hands.

Speaker John Bercow could end up with a casting vote (Picture: AFP)

What about the non-voters?

There are 11 non-voters.

Speaker John Bercow and his three deputies (two Labour, one Conservative) do not vote, while the seven Irish republicans of Sinn Fein do not take their seats.

In the event of a tied vote, convention states that Mr Bercow would make the casting decision.
